author: _samwalker
content: For users who are more price sensitive, but not time sensitive, is there a risk of setting the maxFeePerGas closer to the baseFee, like say `maxFeePerGas = (baseFee * 1.2) + maxPriorityFeePerGas`  or even `maxFeePerGas = baseFee + maxPriorityFeePerGas`.  Currently building out settings for metamask and would like to provide a reliably cheap option for users who have non-time sensitive transactions.

author: sky.cactus
content: We will have to wait for 1559 to launch to see what miners set for the minimum premium, but assuming they are economically rational it should be between 1 and 5 or so.  Once we have more data you can look at the history of inclusion and figure out what their settings are.  For launch, I'm recommending people set like `2` until we have more data.

author: sky.cactus
content: This means you would have `maxFeePerGas = (baseFee * x) + 2` or something.

author: sky.cactus
content: Personally, if you have users who are price conscious I really think the best thing to do is just ask them "what is the most you are willing to pay to include this transaction" and use that for `maxFeePerGas`.

author: sky.cactus
content: There is no reason to set the `maxFeePerGas` to lower than what you are willing to pay.  You should basically *always* set that to be equal to your willingness to pay.

author: _samwalker
content: Understood, it was more that the multiplier `2` in the suggested default of `maxFeePerGas = (baseFee * 2)` seemed like a large range of possibility for some users. Was wondering what the logic behind suggesting that default was.

author: _samwalker
content:
This is one such risk I guess that avoids https://twitter.com/vdWijden/status/1410023932527263745?s=20
Since there's an increased risk of your transaction being kicked now, so a higher multiple also takes that risk into account. So in addition to pending for a long time, a low `maxFeePerGas` also has an increased risk of your transaction being dropped.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is a tradeoff between quoting the user a price that "astronomically high" and "likely to not be included in the next block.

author: sky.cactus
content: 2x feels like it is a nice sweet spot of "most users will accept a fee that is within 2x of their willingness to pay (unlike say 10x)" and "it is very likely the transaction will be included in one of the upcoming blocks".

author: perama
content:
If the timing is serendipitous, two basefee rises might happen in the time between:

- seeing the fee
- clicking accept
- approving on hardware wallet 

So if the broadcast tx is based on a basefee from two blocks in the past, the protocol basefee might be 1.125*1.125 = 1.27x their submitted basefee. 

For this reason alone, submitting with fees around this multiple or less could cause some frustration now and then
